description: From Middle English touchen, tochen, from Old French tochier (“to touch”) (whence Modern French toucher; compare French doublet toquer (“to offend, bother, harass”)), from Vulgar Latin *tuccō (“to knock, strike, offend”), from Frankish *tukkōn (“to knock, strike, touch”), from Proto-Germanic *tukkōną (“to tug, grab, grasp”), from Proto-Indo-European *dewk- (“to draw, pull, lead”). Displaced native Middle English rinen, from Old English hrīnan (whence Modern English rine).

entries.meaning: An act of touching, especially with the hand or finger.
examples: Suddenly, in the crowd, I felt a touch at my shoulder.

entries.meaning: The faculty or sense of perception by physical contact.
examples: With the lights out, she had to rely on touch to find her desk.

entries.meaning: The style or technique with which one plays a musical instrument.
examples: He performed one of Ravel's piano concertos with a wonderfully light and playful touch.

entries.meaning: (music) The particular or characteristic mode of action, or the resistance of the keys of an instrument to the fingers.
examples: a heavy touch, or a light touch

entries.meaning: A distinguishing feature or characteristic.
examples: Clever touches like this are what make her such a brilliant writer.

entries.meaning: A little bit; a small amount.
examples: Move it left just a touch and it will be perfect.
I'd like to see a touch more enthusiasm in the project.

entries.meaning: The part of a sports field beyond the touchlines or goal-lines.
examples: He got the ball, and kicked it straight out into touch.

entries.meaning: A relationship of close communication or understanding.
examples: He promised to keep in touch while he was away.
lose touch

entries.meaning: The ability to perform a task well; aptitude.
examples: I used to be a great chess player but I've lost my touch.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Act or power of exciting emotion.
(obsolete) An emotion or affection.
examples: a true, natural, and a sensible touch of mercy

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Personal reference or application.
A single stroke on a drawing or a picture.
examples: Never give the least touch with your pencil till you have well examined your design.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A brief essay.
examples: Print my preface in such form as, in the booksellers' phrase, will make a sixpenny touch.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A touchstone; hence, stone of the sort used for touchstone.
examples: a neat new monument of touch and alabaster

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Examination or trial by some decisive standard; test; proof; tried quality.
examples: equity, the true touch of all laws

entries.meaning: (shipbuilding) The broadest part of a plank worked top and but, or of one worked anchor-stock fashion (that is, tapered from the middle to both ends); also, the angles of the stern timbers at the counters.
The children's game of tag.
(bell-ringing) A set of changes less than the total possible on seven bells, i.e. less than 5,040.
(slang) An act of borrowing or stealing something.
(UK, plumbing, dated) Tallow.
Form; standard of performance.
examples: Jackson Hately, Isaac Cumming and Nick Shipley have been in great touch in the NEAFL.

entries.meaning: (Australian rules football) A disposal of the ball during a game, i.e. a kick or a handball.
examples: With just six touches, small forward Daniel Rioli was uncharacteristically quiet against Melbourne, although he did lay five tackles.

verbs.description: touch (third-person singular simple present touches, present participle touching, simple past and past participle touched)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make physical contact with; to bring the hand, finger or other part of the body into contact with. [from 14th c.]
examples: I touched his face softly.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To come into (involuntary) contact with; to meet or intersect. [from 14th c.]
examples: Sitting on the bench, the hem of her skirt touched the ground.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To come into physical contact, or to be in physical contact. [from 14th c.]
examples: They stood next to each other, their shoulders touching.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To make physical contact with a thing. [from 14th c.]
examples: Please can I have a look, if I promise not to touch?

entries.meaning: (transitive) To physically disturb; to interfere with, molest, or attempt to harm through contact. [from 14th c.]
examples: If you touch her, I'll kill you.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make intimate physical contact with a person.
(transitive or reflexive) To sexually excite with the fingers; to finger or masturbate. [from 20th c.]
examples: Her parents had caught her touching herself when she was fifteen.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause to be briefly in contact with something.
examples: He quickly touched his knee to the worn marble.
The demonstrator nearly touched the rod on the ball.
She touched her lips to the glass.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To physically affect in specific ways implied by context. [from 15th c.]
examples: Frankly, this wood's so strong that sandpaper won't touch it.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To consume, or otherwise use. [from 15th c.]
examples: Are you all right? You've hardly touched your lunch.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) Of a ship or its passengers: to land, to make a short stop (at). [from 16th c.]
(transitive, now historical) To lay hands on (someone suffering from scrofula) as a form of cure, as formerly practised by English and French monarchs. [from 17th c.]
examples: But in fact the English kings of the seventeenth century usually began to touch form the day of their accession, without waiting for any such consecration.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, obsolete) To fasten; to take effect; to make impression.
(nautical) To bring (a sail) so close to the wind that its weather leech shakes.
(intransitive, nautical) To be brought, as a sail, so close to the wind that its weather leech shakes.
(nautical) To keep the ship as near (the wind) as possible.
examples: to touch the wind

entries.meaning: (transitive) To imbue or endow with a specific quality. [from 14th c.]
examples: My grandfather, as many people know, was touched with greatness.

entries.meaning: (transitive, archaic) To deal with in speech or writing; to mention briefly, to allude to. [from 14th c.]
examples: Next to sorrow still I may annex such accidents as procure fear; for besides those terrors which I have before touched, […] there is a superstitious fear […] which much trouble many of us.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To deal with in speech or writing; briefly to speak or write (on or upon something). [from 14th c.]
(transitive) To concern, to have to do with. [14th–19th c.]
examples: And now it seemed he was engaged in something which touched them closely, but must be hidden from their knowledge.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To affect emotionally; to bring about tender or painful feelings in. [from 14th c.]
examples: Stefan was touched by the song's message of hope.

entries.meaning: (transitive, dated) To affect in a negative way, especially only slightly. [from 16th c.]
examples: He had been drinking over lunch, and was clearly touched.

entries.meaning: (transitive, Scottish history) To give royal assent to by touching it with the sceptre. [from 17th c.]
examples: The bill was finally touched after many hours of deliberation.

entries.meaning: (transitive, slang) To obtain money from, usually by borrowing (from a friend). [from 18th c.]
examples: I was running short, so I touched old Bertie for a fiver.

entries.meaning: (transitive, always passive) To disturb the mental functions of; to make somewhat insane; often followed with "in the head". [from 18th c.]
examples: You must be touched if you think I'm taking your advice.

entries.meaning: (transitive, in negative constructions) To be on the level of; to approach in excellence or quality. [from 19th c.]
examples: There was his mistress, Maria Morano. I don't think I've ever seen anything to touch her, and when you work for the screen [as I do] you're apt to have a pretty exacting standard of female beauty.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To come close to; to approach.
examples: On Sunday afternoon it was as dark as night, with barely room for two riders abreast on a gradient that touches 20%.

entries.meaning: (transitive, computing) To mark (a file or document) as having been modified.
To try; to prove, as with a touchstone.
To mark or delineate with touches; to add a slight stroke to with the pencil or brush.
(obsolete) To infect; to affect slightly.
To strike; to manipulate; to play on.
examples: to touch an instrument of music

entries.meaning: To perform, as a tune; to play.
To influence by impulse; to impel forcibly.
